anchor.surface_text: Whether the order of the Commissioner acting under s. 33B 1  setting aside the order of the Income-tax Officer where an appeal against that order was pending before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner was valid?

issues.text: Does the order passed by the Income-tax Officer granting registration to the assessee firm continue to be an order passed by the Income-tax Officer even after the assessee's appeal against the assessment made by the Income-tax Officer on the basis that the assessee was a registered firm has been disposed of by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner ? In other words, where the appeal preferred by an assessee against his assessment has been considered and decided by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, does the order of registration along with the subsequent order of assessment merge in the appellate order ?

anchor.surface_text: Does the order passed by the Income-tax Officer granting registration to the assessee firm continue to be an order passed by the Income-tax Officer even after the assessee's appeal against the assessment made by the Income-tax Officer on the basis that the assessee was a registered firm has been disposed of by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner ? In other words, where the appeal preferred by an assessee against his assessment has been considered and decided by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, does the order of registration along with the subsequent order -of assessment merge in the appellate order ?

issues.text: whether the order of registration in respect of the assessment year 1949-50 can be made the subject-matter of the exercise of the Commissioners revisional power even though the assessee's appeal against the assessment for the said year is pending before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner at the material time.

anchor.surface_text: The other question which also falls to be decided is whether the order of registration in respect of the assessment year 1949-50 can be made the subject-matter of the exercise of the Commissioners revisional power even though the assessees appeal against the assessment for the said year is pending before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner at the material time.

anchor.surface_text: As we have already pointed out, the department could not challenge the validity of the registration order in the assessees appeal before the appellate authority

holdings.text: The theory that the order of the tribunal merges in the order of the appellate authority cannot therefore apply to the order of registration passed by the Income-tax Officer in the present case.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Registration order under s.26A is independent, not appealable under s.30(1), does not merge in assessment order appealed to AAC under s.31; AAC powers limited to appealable matters.

holdings.text: Such an order can therefore be revised by the Commissioner under s. 33B whenever he considers that it has been erroneously passed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: ITO's registration order remains ITO order post-AAC appeal; erroneous if prejudicial to revenue, revisable under s.33B(1).

holdings.text: We must accordingly hold that the High Court was in error in taking the view that the Commissioner had no authority to set aside the registration order passed by the Income-tax Officer granting registration to the respondent for the years 1947-48 and 1948-49.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects High Court application of merger doctrine; registration separate from assessment.

holdings.text: There can be no doubt that even on the theory of merger the pendency of an appeal may put the order under appeal in jeopardy but until the appeal is finally disposed of the said order subsists and is effective in law.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Pending appeal does not suspend or invalidate subsisting ITO order; Commissioner can revise under s.33B.

holdings.text: We must, therefore, hold that the High Court was also in error in holding that the Commissioner was not authorised in cancelling the order of the respondents registration for the year 1949-50.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No alternative remedy for department; revisional power not limited by pending assessee appeal.

holdings.text: The result is that the view taken by the High Court must be reversed and the first question framed by the tribunal as well as the additional question framed by the High Court must be answered in favour of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the view taken by the High Court must be reversed and the first question framed by the tribunal as well as the additional question framed by the High Court must be answered in favour

holdings.reasoning_summary: Answers questions 1 and additional in affirmative for appellant (Commissioner can revise).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order read as whole directs consequential machinery change post-registration cancellation, not dictating assessment.

holdings.text: We must accordingly answer question No. 3 also in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly answer question No. 3 also in the negative. In the result all the questions framed in this case are answered in favour of the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No fresh notice needed for machinery change (s.23(5)(b)) after registration cancellation; not new assessment.

holdings.text: In the result all the questions framed in this case are answered in favour of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In the result all the questions framed in this case are answered in favour of the appellant.

holdings.text: The Income-tax Officers order granting registration to a firm cannot become the subject-matter of an appeal before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.30(1) limits appeals to specified orders; no provision for department appeal against grant.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay North v. Tejaji Farasram Kharawala  1 ... 1 1953 23 I.T.R. 412

anchor.surface_text: the question raised by the appellant was concluded by the judgment already delivered by it in the Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay North v. Tejaji Farasram Kharawala  1 . In Tejajis case the High Court had held that when an appeal is provided from a decision of the tribunal and the appeal court, after hearing the appeal, passes an order, the order of the original court ceases to exist and is merged in the order of the appeal court and although the appeal court may merely confirm the order of the trial court, the order that stands and is operative is number the order of the trial court but the order of the appeal court.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax Bombay North v Tejaji Farasram Kharawala
precedents.cited_proposition: order of original court merges in the order of the appellate court even if appellate court merely confirms it

precedents.citation: Durgabati and Narmadabala Gupta v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1 ... 1 1956 30 I.T.R, 101

anchor.surface_text: The same view has been taken in the majority decision of the Patna High Court in Durgabati and Narmadabala Gupta v. Commissioner of Income-tax  1 . In respect of the Income- tax Officers order renewing registration to the respondent for the year 1949-50, the High Court took the view that the revisional power of the Commissioner could not be exercised even in respect of this order because the propriety or the correctness of this order was open to consideration by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner in the respondents appeal then pending before him, Commissioner of Income-tax v. Amritlal Bhogilal  subnom   2 .

precedents.case_name: Durgabati and Narmadabala Gupta v Commissioner of Income Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: same merger principle applies preventing revisional power

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Amritlal Bhogilal subnom   2 ... 2 1953 23 I.T.R. 420

anchor.surface_text: the High Court took the view that the revisional power of the Commissioner could not be exercised even in respect of this order because the propriety or the correctness of this order was open to consideration by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner in the respondents appeal then pending before him, Commissioner of Income-tax v. Amritlal Bhogilal  subnom   2 . In respect of this order the High Court had framed an additional question.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v Amritlal Bhogilal
precedents.cited_proposition: revisional power under s.33B cannot be exercised where appeal against the order is pending before Appellate Assistant Commissioner

precedents.citation: Shapurji Pallonji v. Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay  1 ... 1 1945 13 1. T. R. 113

anchor.surface_text: The decision in Shapurji Pallonji v. Commissioner of Income-Tax, Bombay  1  on which Mr. Ayyangar himself relied clearly brings out and emphasizes this position. It is true that the Income-tax Officer is empowered to follow the two methods specified in s. 23  5   a  and  b  in determining the tax payable by registered and unregistered firms respectively and making the demand for the tax so found due but this does not affect the computation of taxable income.

precedents.case_name: Shapurji Pallonji v Commissioner of Income Tax Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: registration of firm affects only machinery/procedure for collection/recovery of tax, not computation of taxable income

precedents.citation: Rex v. The Special Commissioner of Income-Tax  ex parte Elmhirst   1 ... 1  1935 20 Tax Cas. 381

anchor.surface_text: In support of this argument Mr. Ayyangar referred us to the decision in Rex v. The Special Commissioner of Income-Tax  ex parte Elmhirst   1 . The point which arose before the Kings Bench Division in this case was whether, when a notice of appeal has been given, it was open to the assessee to withdraw his appeal and the Court held that once notice of appeal is given the appellate authority was entitled and indeed bound to see that a true assessment of the amount of the taxpayers liability was arrived at.

precedents.case_name: Rex v Special Commissioner of Income Tax ex parte Elmhirst
precedents.cited_proposition: once notice of appeal given, appellate authority bound to arrive at true assessment and assessee cannot withdraw

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: In the result all the questions framed in this case are answered in favour of the appellant.
